facts.text: Two plots of land, Survey No. 37 Kambhapur and Survey No. 137 Narendra, form part of a Watan.
Compensation awarded: Rs. 35,102-10-0 for the two plots.
Reference under s. 30 of the Land Acquisition Act for apportionment between Watandar (landlord, respondent) and person in actual possession (tenant, appellant).
Land Acquisition Judge apportioned compensation 10/15th to landlord and remainder to tenant.
Bombay High Court in F.A. No. 287 of 1953 directed apportionment 55:45 landlord:tenant, holding landlord had right to claim enhanced rent.
In 1863, permanent lease executed by then Watandar in favour of appellant's predecessors at fixed rent of Rs. 727/- per year.
In 1907, Watandar applied under s. 9 Bombay Hereditary Offices Act, 1874 (Watan Act) to declare 1863 lease null and void and for possession.
Assistant Collector rejected the application, refused to cancel lease or give possession.
Collector on appeal (order dated March 16, 1908) maintained rejection but directed additional rent equal to cess.
Government of Bombay order dated May 23, 1911, fixed rent at Rs. 1245/4/- (present rental plus judi plus local fund cess).
In 1926, Watandar applied for further rent increase or restoration; Government order in 1927 fixed rent at Rs. 4300/- and periodic revision every 10 years.
In 1928, tenant sued Secretary of State and Watandar in First Class Subordinate Judge, Dharwar, claiming lands not Watan, acquired Watandar status, and 1911/1927 resolutions ultra vires.

Subordinate Judge held lands part of Watan, Watan Act applicable; 1908 Collector order substantive under s.9(2); 1911 Govt order ultra vires as exceeding Collector-fixed rent but no declaration due to limitation; 1927 ultra vires. Directed no levy beyond Rs.1245/4/- and recovery of excess.
High Court (Beaumont C.J. and Wassodew J.) dismissed appeals except modifying recovery to Watandar only; agreed 1927 ultra vires; held 1911 not under s.9 but sanction of fresh lease under s.5.
Entire Watan 400 acres; acquired lands 30 acres 32 gunthas; proportionate rent Rs.95/9/-; capitalized at 25 times: Rs.2389/1/-.

legal_issues.text: Whether at the date of acquisition, the Watandar (landlord) had right to enhance the rent.
Whether Government order of 1911 was under s.9(2) of Watan Act or sanction of fresh lease under s.5.
Whether earlier High Court decision on nature of 1911 order operates as res judicata.

petitioner_arguments.text: Rent fixed in perpetuity by 1863 lease; landlord has no right to increase rent; entitled only to capitalized value of rent; remainder to tenant.
Earlier High Court decision that 1911 order not under s.9 but sanction of fresh lease operates as res judicata.

respondent_arguments.text: Landlord entitled to enhanced rent; apportionment 55:45.
Earlier High Court remarks on 1911 order were obiter, not res judicata; tenant did not appeal Subordinate Judge's refusal to interfere with 1911 order.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide res judicata as independently, 1911 Government order not under s.9(2) Watan Act but sanction of fresh lease under s.5 at Rs.1245/4/-; only rent changed, permanence and fixity unaltered.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Government acted on basis tenant continues as tenant but at revised rent; sanctioned lease in place of 1863 lease.

court_reasoning.text: s.9 requires declaration alienation null/void first; Assistant Collector refused; Collector agreed implicitly, added cess but no declaration; Government no declaration, fixed rent as sanction under s.5.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No right to enhance rent as lease permanent with fixed rent post-1911.

court_reasoning.text: Landlord entitled only to capitalized value of proportionate rent Rs.95/9/- at 25 times = Rs.2389/1/-; remainder to tenant.

holdings.text: Watandar had no right to enhance rent; entitled only to capitalized value of fixed rent.
1911 Government order sanctioned fresh lease under s.5 Watan Act, not under s.9.

precedents_cited.relevance: If court decision based on multiple points, each operates as res judicata.
Supports res judicata where multiple grounds sufficient for decision.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Hereditary Offices Act, 1874 (Watan Act)
statutes_cited.relevance: s.9 for declaring alienations null/void or recovering full rent; s.5 for government sanction of leases beyond life.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; compensation apportioned Rs.2389/1/- to respondent (landlord, capitalized rent) and remainder to appellant (tenant).

key_quotes.text: "The Watandar had therefore no right to increase the rent."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on fixity of rent.

key_quotes.text: "It is well settled that if the final decision in any matter at issue between the parties is based by a Court on its decisions on more than one point-each of which by itself would be sufficient for the ultimate decision-the decision on each of these points operates as res judicata between the parties."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Government resolution dated 23rd May, 1911 amounts to an opinion to a confirmation of the 1863 lease with a modification as to the rent.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoting Beaumont C.J. on nature of 1911 order.
